UserProfile.title: UserProfile
UserProfile.description: Represents a user within the Finestra Financials application, linked to an external authentication system.

id.description: Unique identifier for the UserProfile entity, typically provided by the external authentication system.

createdAt.description: Timestamp when the user profile was created.

updatedAt.description: Timestamp when the user profile was last updated.

Project.title: Project
Project.description: Represents a financial project with its planned and actual costs/revenues.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Project entity.

userId.description: Reference to the UserProfile who owns or manages this project. (Relationship: UserProfile 1:N Project)

client.description: Name of the client for this project (optional).

startDate.description: Planned start date of the project.

endDate.description: Planned end date of the project.

status.description: Current status of the project (e.g., 'em andamento', 'concluído', 'cancelado').

plannedTotalCost.description: Total estimated cost for the project.

plannedTotalRevenue.description: Total estimated revenue for the project.

actualTotalCost.description: Calculated total actual cost incurred for the project, dynamically updated from associated CostItems.

actualTotalRevenue.description: Calculated total actual revenue received for the project, dynamically updated from associated RevenueItems.

description.description: A brief description or overview of the project.

createdAt.description: Timestamp when the project was created.

updatedAt.description: Timestamp when the project was last updated.

CostItem.title: CostItem
CostItem.description: Represents a single cost entry for a project, including planned versus actual amounts.

id.description: Unique identifier for the CostItem entity.

projectId.description: Reference to the Project this cost item belongs to. (Relationship: Project 1:N CostItem)

userId.description: Denormalized reference to the UserProfile who owns the project.

name.description: A descriptive name for the cost item (e.g., 'Salários - Janeiro', 'Material A').

category.description: Category of the cost (e.g., 'mão de obra', 'materiais', 'marketing').

plannedAmount.description: The predicted amount for this cost item.

actualAmount.description: The actual amount spent for this cost item.

transactionDate.description: The date when the cost was incurred or paid.

isRecurring.description: Indicates if this is a recurring cost.

recurrenceFrequency.description: Frequency of recurrence if 'isRecurring' is true (e.g., 'monthly', 'quarterly', 'annually').

deviationAnalysisNote.description: Notes or suggestions from the deviation analysis assistant regarding this cost.

createdAt.description: Timestamp when the cost item was created.

updatedAt.description: Timestamp when the cost item was last updated.

RevenueItem.title: RevenueItem
RevenueItem.description: Represents a single revenue entry for a project, including planned versus received amounts.

id.description: Unique identifier for the RevenueItem entity.

projectId.description: Reference to the Project this revenue item belongs to. (Relationship: Project 1:N RevenueItem)

userId.description: Denormalized reference to the UserProfile who owns the project.

paymentMethodId.description: Reference to the PaymentMethod used for this revenue. (Relationship: PaymentMethod 1:N RevenueItem)

name.description: A descriptive name for the revenue item (e.g., 'Pagamento Parcela 1 - Cliente X').

plannedAmount.description: The predicted amount for this revenue item.

receivedAmount.description: The actual amount received for this revenue item.

transactionDate.description: The date when the revenue was received or expected.

isInstallment.description: Indicates if this revenue item is part of a larger installment plan.

installmentNumber.description: The sequential number of this installment if 'isInstallment' is true (e.g., 1 for the first installment).

totalInstallments.description: The total number of installments in the plan if 'isInstallment' is true.

createdAt.description: Timestamp when the revenue item was created.

updatedAt.description: Timestamp when the revenue item was last updated.

PaymentMethod.title: PaymentMethod
PaymentMethod.description: Represents a customizable payment method used for tracking revenues.

id.description: Unique identifier for the PaymentMethod entity.

userId.description: Reference to the UserProfile who created or owns this payment method. (Relationship: UserProfile 1:N PaymentMethod)

name.description: User-friendly name of the payment method (e.g., 'Cartão de Crédito', 'Transferência Bancária').

description.description: Further description or details about the payment method.

createdAt.description: Timestamp when the payment method was created.

updatedAt.description: Timestamp when the payment method was last updated.

FixedCost.title: FixedCost
FixedCost.description: Represents a fixed recurring cost that is not directly tied to a specific project (e.g., rent, utilities).

id.description: Unique identifier for the FixedCost entity.

userId.description: Reference to the UserProfile who owns this fixed cost. (Relationship: UserProfile 1:N FixedCost)

name.description: Name of the fixed cost (e.g., 'Aluguel do Escritório', 'Assinatura Software X').

category.description: Category of the fixed cost (e.g., 'Aluguel', 'Utilidades', 'Salários Fixos').

amount.description: The recurring amount for this fixed cost.

nextPaymentDate.description: The next expected payment date for this fixed cost.

description.description: Detailed description of the fixed cost.

createdAt.description: Timestamp when the fixed cost was created.

updatedAt.description: Timestamp when the fixed cost was last updated.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure for Finestra Financials is designed with a strong emphasis on Authorization Independence, Structural Segregation, and clear Access Modeling to ensure robust security rules and efficient queries. The core strategy revolves around path-based ownership for all user-specific and project-specific data.

Authorization Independence is achieved primarily through a strict hierarchical path structure starting with the user's ID (`/users/{userId}/...`). Every document related to a user or their projects is nested under this `userId` path. Furthermore, critical authorization context, specifically the `userId` of the owner, is denormalized into every document that requires ownership checks (e.g., `Project`, `PaymentMethod`, `FixedCost`, `CostItem`, `RevenueItem`). While `Project`, `PaymentMethod`, and `FixedCost` schemas already contain `userId`, `CostItem` and `RevenueItem` (which are children of `Project`) will also explicitly store the `userId` of the project owner. This denormalization means that security rules never need to perform `get()` operations on parent documents to determine access rights, making rules atomic, faster, and less prone to transaction/batching issues.

Structural Segregation ensures that all documents within a given collection share the same security posture. For example, all `Project` documents under a specific `userId` path are private to that user. There are no mixed public/private documents or different access levels within the same collection. This simplifies security rules significantly, as the access logic can be consistently applied at the collection level based on the path and denormalized fields.

Query as Permission (QAP) is inherently supported by this structure. Because all user-owned data is segmented by `userId` in the path (`/users/{userId}/...`), any `list` operation performed by an authenticated user (`request.auth.uid`) can only retrieve documents from their own designated path. For instance, a user can only query `/users/their_uid/projects` and not `/users/another_uid/projects`. This ensures that security rules act as effective filters, preventing unauthorized access even on `list` operations without relying on complex and inefficient database queries within the rules themselves. Similarly, `CostItem` and `RevenueItem` are nested under the specific `projectId` within the user's path, guaranteeing that `list` queries for these items are always scoped to the correct project and owner. This radical consistency in data ownership and access modeling simplifies both rule writing and application development.
